Award.AwardTitle: CAREER:beta-decay experiments to constrain astrophysical processes
Award.AbstractNarration:
The present CAREER award integrates research and educational components focused on the understanding of nuclear properties and their application to the interdisciplinary field of nuclear astrophysics. The main focus of the research is to address the question: How were the heavy elements made? The research component aims at the study of the decay properties of exotic nuclei utilizing the technique of Total Absorption Spectroscopy (TAS). Measurements will focus on nuclei along the rapid-neutron-capture process (or r-process), which is believed to be responsible for the origin of half of the heavy elements. The measurements will build on the previous experience of the PI in the development and use of a Total Absorption Spectrometer and will utilize existing equipment at the National Superconducting Cyclotron Laboratory together with the implementation of new proposed equipment, in this case a tape transport system for the removal of background activity from the detection area.

The technical focus of the research is through the measurement of beta-decay strength distributions of nuclei along the astrophysical r-process. The beta-decay strength distribution is the only reliable parameter for constraining the theoretical models used in r-process calculations and improving their predictive power.

The PI will also establish a unique, new one-week summer school for rising juniors in the area of nuclear physics. The school will be available to 12 students each summer and provide hands-on laboratory activities as well as instruction in nuclear physics. Students from schools that do not offer an undergraduate course in nuclear physics will benefit from this summer school. Ultimately it is important to increase the number of graduate students in the field of low-energy nuclear structure physics, which is important not only for the basic science addressed, but as a training ground for skilled workers in critical areas of homeland security.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award focused on the experimental study of nuclear properties that are important for understanding stellar processes. In particular, the synthesis of heavy elements in the universe has been one of the major open questions of the field of Nuclear Astropphysics. Two processes are considered responsible for the synthesis of the majority of the heavy elements, namely the slow (s) and rapid (r) neutron-capture processes. This award focused on the r process and the nuclear physics input that is critical for its understanding. Within the r process, neutron-capture reactions compete with β-decays to define the flow to heavier elements and the produced abundances. Accurate knowledge of both of these quantities is essential for understanding how this process works and which stellar environments are appropriate hosts. With support from this award we performed several experiments that aimed at constraining both the neutron-capture reactions and the β-decay properties within the r process. We developed a new indirect technique to constrain neutron-capture reactions on exotic nuclei, something that was not previously possible, and applied the technique to medium-heavy nuclei in the A=70 mass region. In addition, we developed a tape transport system that allowed us to perform measurements on nuclei that were not previously possible with the existing setup. Finally, we measured for the first time the β-decay strength distributions of nuclei in the A=70 and A=100 mass regions. The measurements reported here were done at the National Superconducting Cyclotron Laboratory at Michigan State University using the SuN detector.

In addition to the research part of this award, we also had a major educational part. We organized 4 Nuclear Science Summer Schools (NS3) for undergraduate students. The main goal of NS3 was to introduce the field of nuclear science to students who did not have such opportunities at their own institution. A total of 57 students were supported to attend NS3 and participate in lectures, discussions, hands-on activities, networking activities and more. The feedback from the participants was overwhelmingly positive and the school continues under different NSF support.

Finally, the award supported partially two research associates and one graduate student, who performed research within a well structured mentoring plan. The postdocs and students participated in experiments, presented their results at conferences and were active members of the local and national nuclear science communities.
